section.description:
This section is comprised of 50 questions and must be completed within 60 minutes.

The Reading Comprehension section of this test contains reading passages that can be viewed on the same page as the question.

The reading passages are longer than the screen, so they are placed in a window. A scroll bar to the right of the passage can be used to scroll down to read the full passage.

question.text: Tendons contain what type(s) of collagen?
Cartilages contain what type(s) of collagen?
Blood vessels such as arteries contain what type(s) of collagen?

Brenda, a 25-year old female came into the clinic for check-up. Brenda was born with stretchy skin and loose joints. Brenda is 5 months pregnant and wanted to ask about her condition. Which of the following would you tell Brenda?

option.text: Her disease resulted from an inheritable deficiency of collagen-processing enzymes.
Her disease may have resulted from mutations in the protein sequence of collagen types I, II or III.
Her disease only manifests with stretchy skin and loose joints; there are no other potentially lethal problems to worry about.
Collagen containing mutant chains is not secreted and is degraded or accumulated to high levels in extracellular compartments.

question.text: In Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, the collagen types affected can manifest defects in:
Which of the following amino acids maximizes interchain hydrogen bond formation in the collagen triple-helix structure?
Which of the following amino acids causes kinks in the peptide chain of the collagen triple-helix structure?
Which of the following statements is NOT true about fibrous proteins?

option.text: They have axial ratios greater than 10.
They are soluble as hydrophobic side chains in the center of structure.
They have long parallel polypeptide chains with cross linkages at intervals forming long sheets.
Its structure is obtained by combining specific amino acids into regular, secondary, structural elements.

question.text: Anna, a 20-year old female just had her prenatal ultrasound. Her obstetrician told her that the ultrasound revealed bowing of long bones. Which of the following is NOT true about the baby's condition?

option.text: Her baby may have osteogenesis imperfecta.
This type of disorder is severe and may die in utero due to lung problems.
Her baby may suffer from retarded wound healing and twisted spine in the future.
This type of disorder usually presents with fractures due to minor trauma in early infancy.

question.text: Which of the following does NOT describe glycine?

option.text: It is the smallest amino acid
It is found in every 3rd position of the polypeptide chain.
It is the most commonly mutated amino acid in Marfan's syndrome.
Its mutation prevents folding of the protein into a triple-helical structure.

question.text: Which of the following promotes collapse of the alveolar walls if left unopposed?
Marfan's syndrome results from mutation of which of the following?
Marfan's syndrome results from mutation of which of the following?
Which of the following statements does NOT describe type I collagen?

option.text: They are found in supporting elements of high tensile strength.
They form banding patterns under the electron microscope.
They are found in skin, bone, tendon, and cartilages.
Their structure reflects the regular staggered packing of individual collagen molecules.

question.text: True about the different functions of collagen:

option.text: In bones, collagen may be bundled in tight, parallel fibers that provide great strength.
In the cornea of the eye, collagen may be dispersed as a gel that gives support to the structure.
In tendons, collagen fibers are arranged at an angle to each other to resist mechanical shear from any direction.

question.text: Type III collagen:

option.text: Defects in type III collagen can cause potentially lethal blood vessel problems.
Belongs to network-forming group of collagens.
Can be found in distensible tissues such as cartilages and ligaments.
They link collagen fibrils to one another in the extracellular matrix.

question.text: The kidneys and lungs contain sheet-like structures that can function as a semipermeable filtration barrier for macromolecules. Which of the following statements does NOT describe these sheet-like structures?

option.text: They provide mechanical support for adjacent cells.

question.text: Sophia, a 19 year-old cheerleader, came home from a one month vacation and gained weight from 45 kg to 53 kg. She currently experiences difficulty during their group exhibitions and stunts. Sophia now plans to lose weight by skipping dinner and having light breakfast. One morning, she experiences dizziness and body weakness and is rushed to the hospital. At the emergency room, Sophia is found to have hypoglycemia. At this point, which of the following substance is Sophia's main source of energy?

At the emergency room, medications were given to Sophia. She was also told to eat while in the hospital. After an hour, her blood sugar level increased and returned to normal. Which of the following substances helped to increase her blood sugar?

Sophia's mother is a diagnosed diabetic since her childhood and has been treated with injectable medications since then. According to her, she has always been thin and has had frequent hospitalizations due to body weakness and loss of consciousness especially during febrile episodes. In this type of DM, which of the following substances is not stimulated which ultimately leads to fatal complications?
Which of the following statements correctly describes insulin resistance?

option.text: It may pertain to the uncontrolled glucose production of the liver.
It may pertain to decreased glucose uptake by the muscles.
There may be low insulin present but the body does not react to its presence.

question.text: Which of the following statements about insulin is NOT true?

option.text: Insulin promotes breakdown of fatty acids.
Initially, in obese, non-diabetic individuals, insulin levels are high.
Fat accumulation contributes to insulin resistance.

question.text: TRUE about beta cells:

option.text: Beta cells are located in the islets of Langerhans of the pancreas together with 4 other cells.
Beta cells are dysfunctional in type 2 DM because it fails to secrete enough insulin to correct hyperglycemia
Beta cell function deteriorates in type 1 DM due to the toxic effects of sustained hyperglycemia and elevated fatty acids.

question.text: Which of the following statements does NOT describe fatty acids?

option.text: Fatty acids can be used as energy source.
Breaking down fatty acids requires lipoprotein lipase.
Fatty acid accumulation can contribute to insulin resistance.

question.text: Which of the following contributes to insulin resistance?
Which of the following serves as storage form of glucose?

Jose, a 56 year old obese male and self-declared workaholic who works in the office all day and all night long came in to the hospital one morning due to sudden onset of left-sided body weakness with numbness and slurring of speech. Jose was found to have elevated blood pressure and blood sugar. Jose also reported that his other siblings are all diabetic. He also disclosed that he is having difficulty reading the newspaper lately. Based on these findings, which of the statements is TRUE?

option.text: Jose is suffering from non-insulin dependent DM.
Jose is suffering from insulin resistance.
Jose is suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis.

question.text: Which of the following factors are likely predisposing factors leading to Jose's condition?
Jose is suffering from which of the following complications of DM?
Which of the following treatment(s) maybe applicable to Jose's persistently high blood glucose?

While admitted at the ward, Jose said that his son, Mike, a twelve-year old boy is also diabetic. Jose recalled that Mike was diagnosed 3 years ago when he was hospitalized due to high grade fever and lung infection. Jose kept on blaming hims elf for Mike's condition. Jose said that if he wasn't diabetic himself, Mike wouldn't experience the same condition. Which of the following statements would you tell Jose to pacify him?

option.text: Mike's condition might have resulted from physical inactivity.
Mike's condition was a result of diabetes disease from Jose's siblings.
Mike's condition is due to the autoimmune destruction of beta cells.
Mike's condition resulted from his high grade fever and lung infection.

question.text: Mike took the glucose tolerance test. Which of the following would be the likely result?

option.text: After fasting for eight hours, his FBS is 125 mg/dL.
Immediately after a glucose load, his blood glucose increased to 209 mg/dL.
One hour after a glucose load, his blood glucose lowered to 139 mg/dL.

question.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true?

option.text: Polyphagia is not common in non-insulin dependent DM.
Insulin-dependent DM develops gradually without obvious symptoms.
Pregnant women are unable to sufficiently compensate for insulin resistance with increased insulin release.
Deterioration of beta cell functions in non-insulin dependent DM may be accelerated by the toxic effects of sustained hyperglycemia.

question.text: Which of the following statements describes Brucella species?

option.text: Brucella is an indigenous organism that may cause disease in other body sites.
Brucella is normally found in the skin and mucous membranes.
Brucella is a pathogenic organism that usually causes acute illness.
Brucella causes disease when present but disappears spontaneously.

question.text: Which of the following organisms causes infection due to reduced production of complement components?
Which of the microbes easily infect otherwise healthy individuals who have normal host defences but no prior exposure to the microbe?
Which of the following statements about the immune system are NOT true?

option.text: T cells are involved in autoimmune diseases.
Adaptive immunity is found in invertebrates and leads to more rapid and vigorous immune responses.
Indigenous flora refers to commensal organisms that are not truly parasitic.

question.text: TRUE about Corynebacterium species:

option.text: Enters the body through a broken skin
Causes infection when neutrophils are decreased in number
Are indigenous organisms that seldom cause disease

question.text: Staphylococcus aureus, a catalase-producing organism causes infection when there is functional abnormality of:
Which of the following cells of the immune system are responsible for delayed hypersensitivity?
Which of the following cells are responsible specifically for the production of immunoglobulins?

Annie, a 60-year old female, underwent left hip joint replacement last month due to repeated hip joint fractures. Annie was apparently stable and can walk around using her prosthetic joint. She was rushed to the hospital this morning due to high grade fever for three days now. Which of the following organisms might have caused infection in this case?
Which of the following organisms require another organism to cause infection?
Which of the following statements does NOT describe Salmonella?

option.text: It is sometimes resistant to macrophage killing.
It produces a toxin that causes disease in humans.
It can cause infection if inoculated in the blood.

question.text: Jerry, a 25 year old male came in for check-up due to occasional chest pain. He denies any history of heart disease in his family. He also reported on-off cough and sore throat three weeks ago but resolved spontaneously. Upon further examination, he was found to have a damaged heart valve. Which of the following is TRUE?

option.text: Jerry's condition is caused by a transient invasion of foreign microbes in the heart and will disappear spontaneously once microbial invasion is treated.
Jerry's condition is caused by indigenous organisms that are non-infectious in the throat but pathogenic to the heart.
Jerry's condition is an isolated heart problem and needs further work-up.

question.text: Chickenpox, a well-known childhood disease infects humans only once and then builds antibodies against future infection with chickenpox. This is called:
NOT true about indigenous organisms:

option.text: Some indigenous organisms may cause disease in other body sites.
Indigenous organisms usually take the same food as the human host and are thus parasitic.

question.text: Which of the following is NOT true?

option.text: CD4 cells up-regulate the immune response.
The absence of immunoglobulins leads to recurrent infections caused primarily by encapsulated bacteria.
Antibody-mediated immunity tags foreign materials to promote phagocytosis.
Contraction of the urinary bladder muscles contributes to its anatomic barrier against potential pathogens.

question.text: Which of the following organisms cause disease only at the contact site with the host?
Which of the following is TRUE?

option.text: Activated T cells produce antibody after exposure to proper antigen.
Lazy leukocyte syndrome is a severe and recurrent infection due to functional abnormality of neutrophils.
Recognition of self molecules is essential to innate immune system.
